contentrichtext.text: '''Equinox International''' was a [[multi-level marketing]] organization, headed by [[Bill Gouldd]].<ref name=inc1> {{cite web | url = http://www.inc.com/magazine/20001015/20767.html | title = Fast-Sinking Star | author = Donna Fenn | publisher = Inc. magazine | accessdate = 2009-July 6 }}</ref> In the early-to-mid-1990s, Equinox was one of the fastest-growing companies in the [[United States]].<ref>[http://www.npros.com/news/equinox042100.htm Equinox closed by FTC - article from Las Vegas Sun<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It had its headquarters in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. Beginning in 1996, Equinox came under scrutiny for a number of improprieties and illegal acts, including deceptive recruitment tactics. Numerous individuals had filed criminal and civil complaints against Equinox, claiming the firm had swindled them out of money. On 25 April 2000, the [[Federal Trade Commission]] issued a notice that Equinox International had settled the court case with a penalty of $40,000,000 in restitution to the victims of Equinox International. Additionally, Gouldd, the principal of Equinox International, was forced to liquidate many of his possessions and is furthermore barred for life from participating in any network marketing organization in the United States. Equinox International dissolved in 2001. ==References== <references/> {{DEFAULTSORT:Equinox (Mlm)}} [[Category:Defunct companies based in Nevada]] [[Category:Defunct multi-level marketing companies]] [[Category:Pyramid and Ponzi schemes]]
